body: LGTM anyone else?

I would also like to see a better description in this commit message that outlines an example of changed behavior and specifically why. Referencing the issue is also good, but the commit message should also re-iterate the highlights.

@defunctzombie 

Only change would be that escape sequences would be parsed separately as opposed to the entire param parsed as a whole:

``` javascript
// was:
decode("%foobar%24") == "%foobar%24"

// now:
decode("%foobar%24") == "%foobar$"
```

And it is consistent with a querystring module node.js core is using. Although it starts to be inconsistent with qs module used by connect. Ouch.

/me asks @visionmedia about whether difference between qs module and built-in querystring module is intentional or not.

We're bikeshedding, aren't we?

@rlidwka just to appease @defunctzombie, can you add some more comments to the JSDoc? referencing this and the node issue as well as that `%foobar$` example is good - i think that basically covers it.
Zombies are happiest when they are appeased.

working on it... just found this thingy:

```
> querystring.unescape('%2x%25')
'%2x%'
> querystring.unescape('%2%25')
'%2%25'
```

Guys, how unescape should behave in a weird situations that very likely will never happen? :-)

I think we should catch somebody who thinks that **not** throwing 400 error is a good thing (@skeggse, @lxe) and ask them politely to write a spec.

``` javascript
> querystring.unescape('%i %like %to %insert %unescaped %percents %everywhere %because %it %is %cool')
'%i %like %to %insert %unescaped %percents %everywhere �cause %it %is %cool'
//   apparently, this is very useful for development   ^
```

I don't understand all these issues. Why are we not just doing a 500 in a malformed URI? If we introduce subtle handling of weird cases then people will program to those cases and not the standard URI schemes. Isn't it the job of the browser to turn a human typed invalid URI into a proper one?

> Why are we not just doing a 500 in a malformed URI?

Well, it should be 400, because it's a client-side error. See http://node.io/%qusefh for example. And that is what @visionmedia was suggesting in the original issue.

But someone apparently likes doing weird things. :-)
Sorry, I meant to say 400. I think it should be a strict parsing with a 400 response. We have really beat this issue into the ground.

> I think we should catch somebody who thinks that not throwing 400 error is a good thing (@skeggse, @lxe) and ask them politely to write a spec.

Maybe you've misinterpreted my comments; maybe I am misinterpreting your comment. On issue #1734 and PR #1735, I argued that the server _should_ respond with a 400 Bad Request.

> The percent symbol should denote a percent-encoded octet, and o is not a valid hexadecimal digit. You can expect a request to `/%25doesntwork.html` to respond with `/%doesntwork.html`, however, as `%25` is the percent-encoded version of `%`, a request with the path `/%doesntwork.html` should fail. See [RFC 3986](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986), sections 2.1 and 2.4 for more information.
> 
> the fact that express now ignores malformed urls is both counter-intuitive and a potential security threat

I am absolutely in favor of strict parsing, or at the very least making that configurable (which would probably take a performance hit).

> Maybe you've misinterpreted my comments; maybe I am misinterpreting your comment.

Sorry. I have. I tried to quickly determine who has any opinions about it, and didn't pick very carefully.

> Sorry. I have. I tried to quickly determine who has any opinions about it, and didn't pick very carefully.

No problem. I just won't be much help trying to argue against myself. Well I say that...

Yeah, we have plenty of people who think "I would certainly use strict routing and throw 400, but somebody else might be confused, so lets discuss this", and don't seem to have anybody who would actually want lax parsing.
@lxe is your man.
haha i think the consensus is to be strict and throw 400s. if they care, they can complain later!

> There are use cases where handling malformed URIs is necessary, such as proxies that take a proxied URI as a part of the path, for example.

Hmm, if there are real use-cases, can you how such an url would look like?
But if the url is malformed we don't know where to route. Malformed urls are a "pre" express routing issue. When you use a framework you buy into some of the assumptions it makes.

> and navigate to http://localhost:300/%my_malformed_uri

Well, I agree. In this case leaving '%' sign sounds reasonable. But you might want to use spaces in there instead of underlines, so what about `http://localhost:300/%my%20malformed%20uri` ?

> I can deal with it on my own however I please.

Sure, I just checked it, and `app.use(function(req, res){ res.send(req.url) })` works fine with malformed uris. But if you use router, it should parse string to find out where you should route to.

PS: you can deal with it anyway, `app.use(function(err, req, res, next){})` should interrupt such cases.
not sure why we're optimizing for failures, but I'd say being able to handle it in the error-handler would be ok
optimizing for failures is like the essence of node
@rlidwka what's the status on this?

I wanted to ask **lxe** about the difference between http://localhost:300/**%**production and http://localhost:300/**%de**velopment :-)

I don't know... shall I submit another pull request with different behaviour and continue this beautiful conversation there?
doesn't matter to me. just wanted to know the status :)

@rlidwka  this PR actually doesn't really directly affect my argument. You aren't attempting to throw errors... just escape the URL. I'd rather not touch the URL parts at all, but this is sill better than throwing an error.
closing in favor of #1858
